Not just for the gamblers, and not just for tourists either!. Definitely should be part of your itinerary if you are travelling through HK for the first time. This one should be ranked among the major attractions of HK like the peak, the big buddha, the beaches of sai kung, the highest bar in the world at ICC, streets of Soho etc. Lovely atmousphere, with decent people, beer tents, brightly lit, ok food options, and yes as an added bonus you get to take awsome pictures of the night races on lush green grass and brilliant horses while trying your luck at the winnings! :) We've been in HK half a decade and this is still among our favourite middle of the week outing with friends!

Hong Kong action!. Visiting Happy Valley is an interesting experience. Went on a Wednesday night and was able to get in for free as a co-worker's husband was a member of the Jockey Club. I think you can get in for a fairly cheap rate on your lonesome but you might need to bring your passport if you are not from Hong Kong.Anyways, the racecourse is beautiful. Set up against a backdrop of high rises and more distant mountains. the lights, the people, the horses, what an atmosphere. The people of Hong Kong are passionate about horses (?gambling) and the place was electric. A big screen broadcasts how much money has been bet on each race and it is mind-boggling. I placed some bets, had no idea what I was doing, and unfortunately still had to show up to work the next day.There is reasonably priced food/drinks for purchase and they had a band playing in the general admissions section. I didn't see a lot of people drinking but there was certainly a lot of smoking...would recommend checking it out even if you aren't into horseracing as it is such an experience and a big part of Hong Kong's culture/history

Wednesday Night Racing. Had a great time at the course on a Wednesday Night Meeting.£1 to get in, £3.50 for a pint of ice cold Steller and only a £1 a bet.The ex-pats treat it as a real social event so go and soak out the atmosphere.A must when visiting Hong Kong even if you don't bet.

Great fun in the middle of the city. Plan a Wednesday night at Happy Valley. Lots of food choices, not terribly crowded frequently, and pretty easy to place bets. During the day, Happy Valley Racecourse is turned into a city park, where babies can be wheeled in their strollers, and all kinds of multi-ethnic sports games take place. The only negative is that you have to go down and up through an underground concourse to get from the outer rim to the interior.

Great for a night out and a few bets. Massive stands although the public stand at ground level there are pitchers of beers which are great fun for a night out. Its a great setting with the bight lights set amongst the high rise apartments.It was free entry at the time I arrived (830pm) but I suspect if you arrive earlier in the night, 5-7pm, you will have to pay a small fee.

Giddy UP!!!. A great night that is not overly expensive and the racing is fantastic under lights in this city that seems to be obsessed with "the sport of kings". If you are a tourist, take your passport to get entry into the members for HKD$100. it is well worth it, if for nothing else you get personal space (unlike the public areas that are very crowded and with queues for food and drink all night).

a once in a life experience. You cannot go to Hong Kong without going to the race course. The best is to go there by tram which is already an experience by itself. You can have food, drinks and learn how to bet. this was one of my best memories in HK
Gamling big time. More money is bet in a single race at this track then in a whole year at the top California tracks. Exciting place.

Previous trip as Adults wonderful- Unable to go this time with Under 18. This was a trip we wanted to do, as my husband and I have fond memories of an evening out here 25 years ago. Having spoken to our hotel conceirge to book tickets we were saddened to hear we could not take our 17 year old daughter, as visitors have to be over 18 years old. We were travelling as a family with 19 and 17 year old daughters.We were really surprized and the concierge actually phoned through to Happy Valley to check and it was confirmed that by law under 18's are not allowed. We can understand not allowing them to gamble but would have thought that as a tourist attraction the minimum admission age should be lower.

Lot's of VINTAGE TWITS. The races are quaint and arbitrary. Very much like dog races in the English Countryside - some fed dogs, some hungry dogs, a few ferrels and a couple of ringers, all scrambled hard against revolveing door jockeys. The food buffets are to die for.
Great night out. Lots of beer, food options and betting. The betting lines can get long though so make sure to get your picks in early. Really fun.
Great Night Out. Great fun to hang out in the beer area and bet on the horses. Sometimes the betting lines get a bit long so get your picks in early. Good food options and big crowds.

What a location!. You have to try and fit in a visit to Happy Valley. Racing is Wednesday evening and the course is right in the middle of the city surrounded by high-rise buildings. The atmosphere is exciting and happy and the views are good. Proceeds from the betting go to the community and stakes are generally small but the system is very efficient. We joined an organised party and had supper in the visitors lounge which has a panoramic view of the racecourse. Bets could be placed in the room and it had a terrace where you could watch the races.

Good Fun. The horse racing happened to be on the Wednesday after the HK 7s, and we had read reviews, so went along to check it out. Our hotel 'Excelsior' offered a package deal - 5-6hours tour for the night for HK$770. We opted not to take this package, instead walking there ourselves (15minutes) and paying HK$10 each for entry. The atmosphere was electric. So many people. Lots going on - horses and people to watch. Stood right down at the rails and watched the races. Was good fun. Beer and food available. Lots of people around to help with the betting procedures.Is on every second Wednesday at Happy Valley. Recommend.
Night time racing. We took the visitors package which = approximatly $100 pp AUS.Great value... a must do when visiting Hong Kong even if you are not into racing.

Great looking racecourse. Went with a tour group, and had a lovely night, but the meal was just a meal. Had been told that the buffet was excellent, but on our night, not much at all, and the roast meat was not rare, it was basically raw
Enjoyable. Spent a night at Happy Valley Races, WOW the color and the atmosphere was electric. Even if you don't gamble go for the experience.

Great evening. The best places to be here are either the buffet place - seemingly expensive but with a view over the finish line - or in the stands with everyone else, shouting and jeering. Great atmosphere, an exciting evening even if you're not a horse person.

Hong Kong Tea..... It really has little to do with the attraction The Happy Valley, but i happened to have sampled the Hong Kong Tea in the Happy Valley, so i just write about the unique local flavour, the Hong Kong Tea.Happy Valley is a residential area where one will find a lot of expats living here. There are even two drinking pubs adjacent to each other at the south end of the race track. Both are neighbourhood pubs where you will see the local expats drink and eat nightly here. They are very much like the pubs in London, and the whole neighbourhood is very clean and neat. You will find everything that you need to lead a normal metropolitan life in the Valley. I walked along the Sing Woo Road the major artery running south off the Wong Nai Chung road and straight uphill to the mountain, and stepped into a local restaurants where you can have all day breakfast, lunch or anything. I ordered a Hong Kong Tea.Hong Kong tea is a hot beverage made of tea that is from boiling the Ceylon tea leaves in the tea kettle so the acid can infuse in the clear brown liquid. It is strong. To smooth out the caffeine loaded drink, cream or Carnation condensed milk or the Eagle's brand sweet condensed milk is added to enhance the flavour. The concoction is a heavy but smooth acid laced tea with a strong body. It is like drinking a cup of strong coffee. Its uniqueness rivals with the Indian Chai or the Vietnamese Coffee which use heavy cream or condensed milk to smooth out the acid. Interestingly, all such beverages are evolved from their humble beginning of the colonials trying to emulate their colonial masters' refined beverages, but brewed over the time span of an Empire to perfection. i can assure you that this unique beverage is not served in the Peninsula Hotel in TST. If you are into unique drinks, i strongly recommend this hot beverage. I bet you that it is available in hotel restaurants also, but you have to ask for it.
exercise in Hong Kong.. Close to my hotel, not congested, flat, incredible views of surrounding mountains.

Great place for entertainment. Located at the heart of city. A few minutes walk from Causeway Bay Station Times Square Exit(MTR). Go there only while horse racing on Wednesday Night from Sept - June. $10 entrance, enjoy great fun, excitment, food and beer. Gambling not a must, but only there while horse racing!!! (Check with hkjc.com before go)

Surreal. The first outing when we arrived in Hong Kong was to go to the races at Happy Valley. We were hit with everything about Hong Kong; taking the ferry, walking, then getting a tram there. The giant track in the middle of the city is amazing, and the whole experience is pretty delightful & surreal.

Great event. Races here every Wednesday. We had a great time, eating and drinking wine while there. Lots of locals, many just getting off work. This place is right smack in the middle of the city. A fun place to go

Fantastic!!. What a view! Such a good place to visit if you're on holiday in HK or showing visitors around. Public entry costs $10 (that's 1 euro!!), the views are just amazing, where else can you find a racecourse right smack in the middle of such a skyline!! (Well I'm open to correction on this point but this racecourse is pretty special!) Lots of drinking outlets in the public area, food however is a bit limited, it's there but not the healthiest...however you don't go to the races for healthy snacks! Betting is easy, band playing on a Wed night, if you haven't been before, go!
Good food comforts you when you contribute to charity. More delight when you win. Place I go almost every wednesdays. Good Chinese dishes and Western buffets are served at the owners where I go.

A great evening out!. Very simply...go...use general admission for 10HK dollars. Grab a drink, check out the racing card, watch the pre race walk around, place your bets and enjoy! There is plenty of food if you get in the mood for that too. Horse racing in the middle of Hong Kong is so much fun!
Happy Valley is a must!. Great activity, even if you aren't interested in the races. The venue itself is maginificent, being right in the heart of the city surrounded by huge buildings

GREAT night out in the heart of Hong Kong island!!. We love going to the races in Melbourne, but Hong Kong was so different and an absolutely fantastic experience! We had pre-booked dining in a box and it was fantastic value, about $60 Aus including buffet meal, unlimited beer, wine, softdrink, etc. Betting facilities were right nearby and the staff were very friendly and helpful (as we filled in our betting slips incorrectly just about every time!!) The view was fantastic as the stands are right against the track so everything is really close. Went to the parade ring and watched a race up against the fence - the horses were much closer than in Melbourne. Was fantastic. Would highly recommend - if you take your passport and go to the members gate you can pay HK$100 (about $12 Aus) and get into the members enclosure. The VRC at Flemington has a lot to live up to!!! (Oh - keep in mind, no children are allowed.)

Fun morning out.. The hustle and bustle of the horse races at this busy place earns a title for constant excitement. I have never seen so many people bet at the one time amongst a sea of people. You must make a bet and watch the horse of course, and just enjoy the atmosphere

racecourse.. hong kong people are crazy about betting of any kind. including betting on horses. you would think that the real estate is valuable and yet there is a huge racetrack in the little city of hong kong. on top of it, there are many betting offices-- dotted throughout the city.

Well worth a visit. We went to a night race at Happy Valley and had such a fun night. We paid $10 to enter and were able to get up close to the parade ring and the finish line. It has a lot of atmosphere and is a great night out, one not to be missed while in Hong Kong. The magnitude of the place is amazing

Amazing Experience.. Glowing at night. If you are in HK than don't you dare to miss this opertunity to visit racecourse. No need to bet if you don't like to gamble but just go and witness the amazing experience.

Our night at the races. It was reccommended to us Happy Valley races, on the 8th floor Dining room great meal we could bet on the races and watch them from there.We received $30 hong kong also to bet and even for people who don't follow races we had a ball then we went down on to track to watch race recommend it

A great experience. Wow - what an amazing night out. We enjoyed the Racing in Style package which included level 9 seating with balcony and waiter service. Food was a buffet - with fantastic desserts.This is a truly worthwhile evening at a racecourse like no other right in the centre of Hong Kong. We even backed a winner!

A unique night out at the races!. Twinkling lights surround the racecourse, you can spend 150hk with your passport going into the Jockey Club or just 10hkd to go through turnstiles and join in the fun. Really great night out - and don't worry if you have never bet at the horses before, all the staff are super helpful.

And the Winner is.... We have never been to a racetrack, but this turned out to some of the best fun we had in Hong Kong. As tourists, showing a passport will gain you entry to an upgraded area, on the track level next to the finish line and where the horses promenade. Pitchers of beer were there to be had, and a "party" atmosphere was present. You could probably bet on a horserace, but we already felt like winners from the experience. Getting there and back? Taxi turned out to be just fine.
Horse Racing. A lovely horse racing park right in the middle of the city. Stay at the Cosmopolitan Hotel, right across the street for lovely accomodations.
Good. A good night out, booked the tour, but Sha Tin is much better. Also they ran out of potatoes on the buffet, not long after we got there and we had to settle for hash browns. Not very good.

Great Night Out, just make sure you pre-organise getting home. This is a great night out. We bought the Tourist Pass recommended on their website, but it was not really needed, as all the action was down in the beer garden, close to the track and is only HK$10 to get in. Extremely well organised of course like everything in HK with plenty of event staff on hand to help you place your bets.The only downside of the night was getting home (if you're staying on Kowloon). As Happy Valley is on HK island, none of the taxi drivers want to go back to Kowloon that late at night and we found ourselves stuck.My husband came up with the bright idea of getting a taxi to HK Central MTR (as taxi drivers WOULD take us there) and then MTR'ing it back to Kowloon. Other than that, well worth a visit.
Convenient Living Community. It might not be so good for tourists. But a nice place for living in Hong Kong
Night out at the races. This was a great night out, booked through the Tour Desk at Hotel, very good price, included transfers, buffet, drinks, vip treatment, brilliant night.

It's a winner. Fun, buzzy, glam! You can feel the attraction of money and success, it's very like the yuppie era of entreprenuership in the 1980s. It's ten Hong Kong Dollars to get in (82p). Drinks are expensive though but plentiful. Didn't bet myself but I believe it's easy enough and there's automated machine bettting too. If you're at a loose end on a Wednesday night, it is THE thing to do: the atmosphere is electric! The ability to get close up to the horses and feel the cheering rise up into the Hong Kong night sky makes it a floodlit experience like no other.TIP: Take a happy valley ding ding tram for 2.3 HKD (that's about 20p and a joy to the ears of us on budgets), take it all the way to the end of the line. On alighting, move forward and round to the right where the entrance ot the race course becomes apparent - Octopus can be used to get in too.

certainly has the wow factor. Horse racing was the main reason for our visit to HK. We weren't disappointed. The sheer size of this racecourse is something to see. Overlooked by hundreds of skyscrapers it's awesome. We were with friends in a corporate box, the catering was excellent, which is not always the case at these type of events. The only down side was getting out of there at the end of the meeting. There aren't enough lifts for the number of guests so be prepared to wait and wait. I still recommend it as a must for all racing fans.

You'd be nuts to miss this!. Not for the kids but top horse racing venue with OK food, plenty of beer and its easy to get a good view. We go about once a quarter. Sometimes we go in a corporate box with catered everything other times we're at trackside both equally as much fun. If the weather is not good just dress up warm there are plenty of places to shelter. HV is in easy walking distance of many restaurants and bars too so go before or go after just make sure you know where you're going.Happy Valley is a great night out and cheap as chips to get in. Tourists should not miss it and expats will go again and again.
One of the world's great race courses.. If you like horse racing then you are in for a treat. If you don't still go as it is a lot of fun and right in the middle of town. Tremendous fun.
Best Racecourse in Asia.. An excellent night out, racecourse is brilliant. The locals take their horse racing very seriously!
Great night out. This is part of what Hong Kong is all about, Go on a Wednesday night, sit in the beer garden it is a great night.
Go Wednesday night. Its a party every time. Lots of fun, cheap beer and the food is good. Women are amazing there!

Where else to spend your Wednesday evening?. Where else in the world do you have a racetrack right in the middle of a city? Dont need to gamble, great place to meet friends/colleagues in the "beer garden" on the ground level. Great atmosphere!
Night racing. Superb event great racing and dinner was very good too
Incredible. Take an organised trip , very reasonably priced , great food and drink , and abvove all , great racing !

Old and boring. Unless the visitor wants to help enriching the local Jockey Club, I see no point whatsoever for going there and waste time. It's not pretty, there's nothing interesting, it's hot and humid, in short it is just a place for sport class to come and have a sweat. Worthless.

Got any good tips?. Pay the extra and have the dinner buffet on the balcony where you can eat a superb range of foods and drink unlimited beer or wine and participate in the racing - Happy Valley is mainly on Wednesday evenings and it is great fun
Great Evening. Went in the public enclosure for $10 entry. Great atmosphere and really enjoyable evening. Would definitely go again.
Spectacular Horseracing. You can't get anything like it in Europe or America! The dinner buffet is not cheap but one should just experience the atmosphere of the biggest betting machine in the world.
no better way to spend a Wednesday night. 10 HKD to get in. great setting and great fun. Even if you don't wager it's a fun evening.

Super huge!. It was better than you would expect! On the ground floor there is alot of western people and a lot of beer and girls selling beer. On the upper floors there is local people betting on horses. It was quite hard to bet, because we did not understand anything, but people were happy to help us! You should definitely see this!

Great fun - they run once a month - enjoy!. You need to book into the Members and guest box - this gives you a proper table, a descent Dinner and private betting at your table. We had 3 Winners out of a 12 race card so the racing is fair and pretty easy to pick up quickly. Enjoy the night at Happy Valley, they have racing outside Wan Chai out of town at Sha Tin Racecourse which is where the Hong Kong Derby is run (they race at Sha Tin once a month as well)Have a look at www.hkjc.com for the info and enjoy!
Fantastic atmosphere. Where the Hong Kong people enjoy a good night out. We even won!

For all those Punters. A great day spent at the races. We found it very hard to make a bet until we finally found a guide that we could read. Had to make a few bets in a row as the ques to put on your bets gets hectic - as we all know the chinese are the biggest punters.

Amazing Facilities, Food and Atmosphere. We attended this race course via a package purchased through Splendid Tours.They offer transport, admission, drinks (unlimited), 3 course meal, betting voucher and book for around $110AUD.Great value for money!The track is situated in the middle of a business precint.It is amazing to see workers from the surrounding areas come to the track after work in their suits and ties.The racing is awesome. It was a night meeting we attended.The food, service and amenities are first class.The meal and drinks were as much as you could eat and drink.I would suggest a limited food intake across the day!If you book this tour or just attend the track you will not be disappointed!

Top night out for all budgets. Went on a Wednesday night (you can check the schedule online). If you go to the members entrance and produce your passport for an extra couple of pounds/USD you are given access to the members areas of the racecourse. This means a couple of extra restaurants/higher tiered seating and to the paddock. Well worth it.Minimum bets were 10HKD, so if you are on a small budget you can join in the fun without breaking the bank. The Chinese love their horses, so it's part of a culture that is worth seeing.
A fun evening. We all spent a great evening here the view was spectacular

horse power!. great vibe! cheap beer! but i think one should check the schedule of horse racing before heading over. we almost went to the wrong one! other than that, it's perfect! (except that i lost my bets)

An lovely evening.. A bit pricy but booked in the foyer of the Excelsior hotel and the price included pick up and return from the Excelsior and one other place in Kowloon I think. Evening buffet meal european style with Chinese overtones, wine with the meal, a fantastic evening view from the balcony outside a higher level of the Jockey Club from where you can get a view of the whole racecourse, a visit to The Parade ring and a credit slip for 30 HK dollars all in the price. Very atmospheric and the view from the Jockey Club Balcony is thrilling. You get the pulse of racing in the blood evening if like me you are not a betting person. The betting system is not clear as there are more opaque betting options but they must be types of accumulator. Just a lovely environment without the hassle of crowds if you go for the Jockey Club evening. It is the same feeling as a cabaret night out.Our Lord taught me to trust him for all my needs and not to attempt to get rich quick but some people never learn this and horseracing is not a pleasure but a headache of trying to pick winners and getting desparate when that fails.Think of good food, a visual spectacle and take good company with you but you should meet no aggression on this trip.Chris, Anna & Jordan
Chill Out. A great way to spend Wednesdays feeling the pulse of Hong Kong
Have a bet for fun !. Just 5 minutes walk from the Cosmo Hotel is the Racecourse. It is very cheap to get in and have a few small bets for fun. It was a little noisy during the races...lol.

Race night.. Many people visit the races in groups and hire a box for the evening, but you can pay $10 and walk in and stand with the masses. A super atmosphere if you like this sort of thing. A fortune changes hands at each race meeting and you can feel the tension. Meals are provided in the boxes but I'm not sure if you can partake if you arrive without booking, You can catch the Happy Valley tram and go around the race course in the day time to give you an idea of the size. There is also Sha Tin racecourse where you can walk to the area in the middle of the tracks and picnic.

Fun to watch. This was a pretty fun activity to do, even if you're not into gambling. I went to one of the Wed night races (start times: 7-7:30pm) and took in about 3 races. Each race lasts for a little over a minute, and it's about 30 minutes between races. Most of the fun comes from the anticipation, scouting out the horses before the race and listening to dreamers scream out their lucky numbers in hopes of being able to spur their selected horses on to victory.The atmosphere is alive and the track is a pretty fun place to hang out with your friends or co-workers. I can see why the locals like coming here.

Night Racing. We went to the last night races before Christmas. It was not as busy as I had expected but by no means quiet.The customer information desk in the betting hall were very helpful providing form guides and explaining how to fill in the betting slips.

Great night out. Had a great night at Happy Valley racecourse during our visit to Hong Kong. Apart from the fact that we won a few dollars, the atmosphere was great and the sight of the skyscrapers overlooking the racecourse was spectacular.The entrance few was only €1 which makes it great value and there are plenty people on hand to help people who are not familar with betting.Well worth a visit

A fun-filled night in Hong Kong whether you are a punter or not. Happy Valley races are a must when in Hong Kong. The vibe is electric, the food stalls offer many cuisines ( there is even a Maccas) and the drinks are reasonably priced. Also, they often have a theme for the night and special discounts, I haven't mentioned the horse races - but they are always there. A great night out in Hong Kong!

Fun Night Out. Most Wednesday nights, Hong Kong holds its night horse racing which is a fun event to attend. Because we were tourists, we showed our passport at the ticket office near the members entrance and paid just 100 HKD (so around $12AUD) which gave us access to the general area as well as part of the members stand, including level two and the arena where the horses parade before the race. My only complaint would be the quality of food offered in the cafeteria on the second level ... a bit average but I suppose what do you expect for around $8. Even though we didn't back any winners, we had a great night out.
Fun Summer Activity!. I went with three friends, and we had a blast. No prior understanding of horse racing necessary. We stayed watching the races for about 3 hours -- and made a bit of money too!

a night at the races. If you can get a Tourist pass for dinner at the races in a box, then do it. However, it's also fantastic fun to go down in the stands to really feel the excitement and feel the horses as they go thundering past.

Possibly the best night out in Hong Kong. Possibly the best night out in Hong Kong for fun, entertainment and atmosphere. I have been several times and would recommend going to the public enclosure at track level rather than to one of the restaurants to get the most from the experience. Entrance here is just HKD10 and there are plenty of options to get food and drink.There are normally around 8 races and betting is a tote system which may seem a little complicated at first but there are assistants around to help and those taking the bets are very patient when you fill the betting slip in incorrectly (which I did most of the time). The minimum bet for each race is HKD10 and so it need not be an expensive night with the excitement of some potential winnings to come.The setting is quite special in the middle of urban Happy Valley which seems to add to the buzz. Giant outdoor screens in the centre of the track allow you to follow the action at all times.Traffic to Happy Valley can be very congested so plan ahead to male sure you arrive in time.Thoroughly recommend it.

Spend a fabulous Wednesday evening here. No dislikes,just a very exciting time at this great world famous horse racing venue. NOT TO BE MISSED.There is a large selection of places from which to view the racing from corporate boxes to the public area which is very cheap to enter

the can't miss experience of Hong Kong. The most unique racetrack in the world. Towering grandstands rise above a tight-turning turf track, creating an ampitheatre like no other. 20,000 regularly attend on a Wednesday night.Cheap admission, beer garden and live music.

A fun night out. Pretty much a must see if you're visiting Hong Kong - the only urban race course that I know of. Well, I've been to the dog track in Oxford as a youth, but that's not the same as watching horses run around, scant metres from one of the busiest metropolises in the world.If you haven't studied the form of the horses, you can just pick the ones with the silliest names and you'll probably enjoy the same luck. Bets are easy to put on, almost as easy as going to the beer tents dotted around the track - if you like lots of drunk Westerners yelling and dribbling beer, then you'll like it here. If you detest that, maybe you'd do better visiting on a weekend or the Sha Tin race course (event meetings alternate between the two venues, which you can check on from the Hong Kong Jockey Club's website for an up to date schedule).
Not just for racing. In the centre there are a number of pitches, mainly football, and also a a jogging track. If you feel in need of exercise it is free, once you have found the way in!

Great entertainment away from usual LKF thing. It was my first experience to watch the horse race and it made me fall in love of HK all over again. Even if you have no idea about horse racing you will have a great time. The atmosphere was amazing and we were lucky it was during Oktoberfest so there were food and beer galore. If you're in town next, try to watch the races. heaps of fun!
Exciting. Cool and is recommended to try your luck.Even though I loss

the ultimate racing experience. This is the home of the finest racing in the world. Not only is the highest amount of money bet per race card, but it is also the most competitive racing in the world. And the setting with the tall buildings of Hong Kong all around just enhances the experience. Whether you are a racing fan or not, do not miss this place.
Happy Valley Racecourse. Visit the happy valley racecourse club, had a buffet dinner in the club. Variety of food, sashimi was very fresh.
Fantastic night out. The best way to spend a wednesday night in hong kong, even if your not into racing. It has to be the most unique race track in the world.

Great fun. Wednesday's the best night. The locals are fanatical about horse racing. Make sure it's a real race at the racecourse as they sometimes just pack the crowds in to watch live racing on big screens. I don't think that happens on the Wednesdays though??

Amazing Place! So Exciting to be here!. The rush you get when you walk into the horse tracks is unbelievable. There are so many people cheering, hanging out, and enjoying their time there. The adrenaline is crazy as 1000s of people root for their horse. I can't believe how many people were there. We were able to find our way around the place to start making bets. It was a lot of fun. Make sure you are watching outside. There is a lot of alcohol, so if you aren't interested in horses and interested in drinking, then this is a good spot too.All the lights and people make this place a sight to see. The only complaint is that there aren't enough seats for everyone, so be ready to stand!

horse Racing Venue. A convinient located area called Happy Valley, lots of 24 hours shops there, the 7/11, now coming back to the reacecourse it is just like seeing the horses in 3D live, and looking at the horses which are a few steps away from the crowd, One does not have to be a jockey club member to enter in the racecourse, I like it as muc as you do.
Beautiful Racecourse. Fantastic and exciting experience. Get there early for a reserved seat.

Wednesday night fun. Happy Valley racecourse - always bustling on a Wednesday night and a great atmosphere. The track is very sharp, so try to get some local knowledge and back front-runners with a low barrier draw. We went in the Members grandstand, which had more space but you wouldn't miss out on anything in the 'ordinary' enclosure which has only a 10 dollar (£1) admission charge.The sight of tower blocks looming over a brightly lit racetrack is an iconic Hong Kong view. Get here on the tram - you'll find that they run extra services on Wednesday evenings.
Incredible!. Enjoyed the buffet which offerred the best selections of many asian delights and a delicious french petite desserts. Great service!
Horse Racing. Went here as a package tour, drinks & dinner included. Great especially if you like horseracing.

A great night out. The atmosphere here is terrific. The night we went there was an Octoberfest celebration. There was also a typhoon warning in operation so not many people about at the start but more arrived as the night progressed. It was a fun night.
Good entertainment. Went here one evening & really had a great time. Well wort a night out.
Restaurant. You must try the restaurant - Amigos. It is worth every penny, leave the kids at home as it is a grown up place.

Interesting the see racecourse and people betting !. The entrance is 10HK$. Then you can bet if you want.
You can find there many stands for eating and drinking.
Really interesting to see people around you betting. Many different kind of gambler.
Wednesday at Happy Valley is a must for a visit. Take the tour bus to the experience you won't forget. I would definitely recommend this experience. Plenty of crowd and betting.

Great Experience for All. For a nominal fee you can have a great night out (usually held on Wednesday evenings). You can have a flutter on the races for a very small stake (on the 'Tote') or just enjoy the colour and atmosphere.

Another unique HK experience. I can't think of another horse race track which sits overshadowed by high-rise apartment blocks in the centre of a major city. The setting is stunning and the floodlit racing is atmospheric. The view (and the food) from the stands is excellent. But best of all is the thought that when you lose your shirt the profits will all be going to HK charities.

A different experience. It's wednesday night at the races and a first time for me. Rode the Happy Valley tram and used my octopus card for the HKD10 entry fee. The atmosphere was festive, like an Oktoberfest with all the beer, bright lights,handsome horses and with some side shows in betrween races.Lots of food concessionaires (There's even a McDonalds stall) and souvenir stalls. Just watching the people around was a totally different experience.
Great. Pick up a tourist pass at the Jockey Center (HK$100), and enjoy the view from the race course.
Great Experience!. We love the races, it is not quite like the races in Australia but you can have a great meal and bet at the same time! It is worth the visit!

Good fun and easy to get to.. Took the tram from the hotel, 10HKD entry using Octopus, stayed for a few races then walked back via Causeway Bay.
Definitely recommend for the experience.

Great experience!. The people that brought us there had a paid membership, so we did not have to pay to get in and were in a private section, away from the ground crowds!I must say it was crazy busy on the wed night, there were all sorts of people! Tourists, business people, cityfolk! It's a great experience, I won over 500 from a 20 dollar bet! The thrill and atmosphere is great!Stop while you're ahead and don't go too crazy with the gambling!Even if you dont gamble the environment there is a must see!
a great night out. Book for race night and go to dine at the course and enjoy the racing.Deal includes meal drinks and you have balcony to watch the races...Fantastic experience and night

Wednesday night fun. Make sure you go on a Wednesday night. Cheap to get in, beers on the balconys and plenty of people to talk to. Check out the locals taking the betting very seriosly and take a long a small amout to bet yourself. Lots of quick races so not too much sitting around. It will take a while to leave the stadium if you go right at the end so dont plan to rush anywhere.
Wed is racing night 7PM. races are fixed so just go there for the crowd and the beer

Great night out!. Fantastic night out although it somewhat helped that I picked 4 out of 8 winners! It is definitely worth paying the $100 tourist rate which gets you into the members area and right up the front of the parade ring and in line with the winning post. Don't forget your passport though. Very easy to bet and never any queues at the kiosks and staff are very helpful if you are not too sure of how to fill the slips in. To help you choose your horse they provide free form guides/tip sheets which came in useful. Beer garden sells different beers at very reasonable prices ($34 for a pint of San Miguel) and the chicken kebabs were very tasty and filling. Unless you are travelling by road then there's no real need to leave before the last race as recommended by some as it's about a 15 minute walk back to the MTR and I didn't experience any big crowds or queues at the station.  A very enjoyable and entertaining night and the racecourse is in a lovely setting with all the high rise buildings lit up around it.

An Evening at the Races. We booked the escorted tour through Splendid Travel. It lived up to the name. Evening racing at Happy Valley is without parallel. The site is awesome. The sight is thrilling. Our guide explained the betting system clearly. I lost a few $HK. My wife came out well ahead.The range of food on the intercontinental buffet was slightly disappointing - mbut was adeqaute in quality and volume.Altogether a splendid evening- and will be repeated if we return to Hong Kong
Fantastic. The best night's racing you will ever get, for atmosphere!

great fun!. I dont know how... but i won!!!
We went on a night tour that gave us box, meal and betting access without having to leave our nice, safe, touristy area (lol). Good fun

Great night -must do. I am not normally a racegoer but what a great night. Run on Wednesday nights-fantastic facility -great spectacle. Staff are friendly - possibly best customer service when asking for directions or just answering our questions. Watch the racetrack staff appear after each race to stamp down hoof prints on the synthetic track. You might get lucky and have a win. great experience - must do and well priced
Good hangout place after work on Wed. I went on Wednesday. It was packed with both locals and foreigners, many of whom seemed to have just gotten out of work. It was like a big outdoor party.

A Must-Do in Hong Kong. Races usually take place on Wednesday nights at Happy Valley and provides some of the best evening entertainment to be had in Hong Kong. Great racing, plenty of food and drink and a wonderfully noisy atmosphere!

What a great time!. If in HKG and on a Wednesday night, go to the Happy Valley Racecourse! Price is right and show the passport! Just a great place to watch horses and people and drink great priced beer.

Super experience. The HKJC do an amazing job of setting race nights up for tourists to easily have a fantastic experience.Tourist badges are only $10 and get you basically all access passes where you can enjoy great views over the right circuit from the stands, or be in the thick of the atmosphere down along the fence where the beer garden attracts many.There are staff everywhere to assist you in any possible question you might have, and the food upstairs in the members enclosure was fast yet sensational, and cheap!Definitely worth a night out if a race meet is on!
Another market. If you have already visited the markets in Kowloon, then Stanley Market will not impress.
A great experience. No need to dress up, only $10 to get in or use your Oyster card. Great fun but leave before the last race to avoid the crowds.
Great Night Out. Cheap to get in and a low minimum bet so you can make this a cheap night out if need be.Great atmosphere and good fun.Lots of staff around to help you if your a first time racegoer

An authentic Hong Kong experience. The Hong Kong Jockey Club has a weekly meet at the Happy Valley racecourse on Wednesday nights year round except during summer (approx June to Sept) as the weather is too hot and humid for the horses. Apparently, a weekly meeting sees more bet than the entire Spring Racing Carnival in Australia including the Melbourne Cup! We entered General Admission which costs HK$10 (US$1.20) to get in and allows you to go anywhere you want on the ground level next to the final straight. There are a bunch of beer stalls and lots of cheap food options here including McDonalds (!), plus plenty of betting stalls. What is surprising is that it's quite easy to get a spot right up on the rails, which will allow you to really feel the horses thunder by when the races are on. The expats will generally hang out next to the rails on the grass and will treat this as more of a social affair, while the locals tend to take the punting sheets and betting a bit more seriously. The night starts around 7 or 7:30pm and the last race is around 11pm. Happy Valley is an easy 10 minute cab from Central (which might cost around HK$40 or US$5-6) or you could catch the tram which will drop you right outside the main entrance. The traffic can be a bit busy after the last race so you could consider leaving after the second last race to beat the crowd.

Best night in Hong Kong. We visited on an organised trip.What a wonderful experiance. We had a box over looking the race track which we shared with about a dozen other people. At the back of the boxes was a betting counter so that you could easily place bets. There was also a fabulous buffet that you could help yourself to with lovely chinese and european food. All drinks were included and your glasses were top up as soon as they started to get low. We were then taken down to the winning line to watch the end of a race from the winners enclosure. The setting for the course is breathtaking a large green track surounded on all sides by sky scrappers. I would have happily spent 3 or 4 nights here it was easily the best night we had in Hong Kong and I would love to visit again.

Central Park Meets Horse Racing - Yes Please. Went with my girlfriend and a couple of New Yorker friends. After arriving in Hong Kong and already feeling this strange nostalgia for New York we then discovered the Happy Valley Racecourse. Wow.Bright green grass, pitchers of beer, foreigners / ex-pats everywhere, asian men gambling to their hearts content... all surrounded by the Hong Kong skyscraper jungle.If you're in Hong Kong and the races are going on (I believe they happen on Wednesdays, but read other reviews to be sure) this is a must.

What a spectacle!. We visited Happy Valley racecourse and was definitely impressed. Just a short taxi ride from our hotel to the course, and entrance fee paid by Octopus $10 which is just so cheap (around $2 in NZ money). Like everything in Hong Kong, entry to the venue was efficient. We are not into horse racing at home, but enjoyed the HK experience just wandering around the public area, and into the stands, seeing the horses parade, race and the lights. Food was a chicken kebab from a stall which was all we needed and we resisted the temptation of McDonalds. While there, there was an Australian/New Zealand wine promotion, so tried a local NZ wine (served in a plastic cup). Races every half hour, and the time between these goes quickly. Rather than wait for a tram, again returned to hotel by taxi, the queue for taxis looked rather long, but it moved very quickly.

Fun, even if horse racing is not your thing. Getting there was a little hassle, took the MTR from TST area, but the MTR station near the Happy Valley Course is far away from the actual stadium. took us nearly 20 minutes to walk and of course the non-member entrance is the furthest away around the stadium. Entry was easy and cheap with the octopus card. We came around between the 3rd and 4th races, so there were no lines. There was a wine festival when we went, so we bought a pass to try 8 wines from 6 different countries, nice deal. Also had a kebab and a sausage platter. Good price and quality for stadium food. Made a few bets, it was confusing trying to make those, but there are staff attendants to fix any mistakes when you place them. Collecting was easy. We left just after collecting our bets from the 7th race. jumped onto a packed tram which we were told was going somewhere else, but managed to get off at an MTR station anyway, and make it back to our hotel. I'm not the biggest fan of horse racing, but this night out was a lot of fun for the atmosphere and people watching. Would be a great date place for me.

What an experience. We love the races so we didn't miss the opportunity to go to Happy Valley. It didn't disappoint - what an experience. The night races are in a spectacular arena with tens of thousands of people attending each race meet. . Even if you are only slightly interested in racing don't miss a trip to Happy Valley. We did the Spendid Tour recommended by our Hotel and we thought it was very reasonable considering all the inclusions. It is a great night out and one of the highlights of visiting Hong Kong.

A splendid night. As avid race goers we couldn't let a trip to hong kong pass without heading out to happy valley. We elected to go on a tour - using splendid tours and we were pleasantly surprised by the value and experience. The facilities the tour provides access to were excellent, the buffet was reasonable and the tour staff worked hard to ensure we got the most out of the evening . We had the chance to meet new people and that really made the night !

part of hk culture. Horse racing or gambling in general are part of hong kong culture. You therefore shouldnt miss to visit one of the best places for this in hk: the happy valley racecourse.its located in happy valley which is easy to access by public transport. The tram is only one of various possibilities to reach it.HK people may watch the races on tv and bet using the internet but for me its simply not the same. The racecourse has enough stands to oversee the races and an entertaining and exciting evening is pretty guaranteed.The place is also good to meet people, if you stay in hk for a longer period. On Wednesday a lot of interns meet-up there.

much more fun than just watching on TV. been to the races at happy valley on wed night for several times and was a blast!it's a great place to watch horse races in real, must more exciting than on the TV. So close to the horse and even you have feel the breeze when they are racing.moreover, just notice they will have Oktoberfest celebration every year at the beer garden inside the racecourse. should be cool. Fun.

It's a great night. I had recently visited Hong Kong, Macau and Singapore and being a bit of a punter, I was looking forward to this night as the highlight of my trip and it didn't disappoint.First of all, it does require some planning to get there if you choose public transport. I was staying in Mong Kok so I took the MTR to Admiralty then changed onto the Island Line and got off at Causeway Bay. Was about a 10-15 minute ride from there to the track.I did go for the HK$100 tourist member pass but in hindsight, all you need is the general HK$10 entry. The first couple of races were reasonably quiet, I noticed that after most people came between the 2nd and 3rd races and the racecourse filled up very quickly so it was difficult to get a seat in the grandstand, so get in early and get a seat if you need one.The racecourse was really well set up. It was an interesting mix. The Chinese origin crowd tended to occupy the members seats near the finish line while the ex-pat crowd seemed to favour a "party area" down near the 200 metre mark where there were several beer tents and music playing between races.Also in that area were staff from the HKJC who were helping put bets on.All in all, I had a great night (probably helped by the fact that I backed 2 winners at reasonable odds. It's always good to leave the track with more money than what you went with). I left the track after the 2nd last because my feet started getting sore. As I was leaving, I noticed a very long taxi line beginning to form with very few (none actually) taxis at the rank. I grabbed a tram back to Wan Chai and caught the MTR back to Mong Kok so I would suggest you look at finding an alternate means to leaving at the end of the night than a taxi because you could be waiting for a while.

Great experience!!!!!. Very nice experience and great time for a different night!Next time I will be in Hong kong I will definitely go back!The only negative point is that you can not get a good dinner inside, I would recommend to go there after dinner!

Surprisingly FUN!. Happy Valley was surprisingly a very fun night. We did not buy the tourist pass, we just entered at the general admissions gate for $10HK. As we were walking around the stadium to that gate, we did notice the swankier crowd entering through other gates. I don't know if this was for the tourist level or not. We were at track level and as you enter on your left, just past the McD's stand there are a bunch of gentlemen in blue jackets standing there to help you place bets. We had never been to a horse race before and we quite clueless. They spoke English well and were very helpful. The gentleman who helped us was very friendly and infectiously happy. We were too after we won 3 out of 4 races we bet on! Go - you can't not have fun!

Fun, but chaotic. As with the last reviewer, what should have been an excellent evening was heavily marred by an incomprehensible labyrinth of corridors, lifts and zones. With hindsight, we shouldn't have bothered with the faff of taking our passports to obtain tourist passes, and we should have stuck to the public areas further down the course. From what we could see the public area had plenty of facilities and was close enough to the start/finish line to get in on the action. By contrast, with the tourist pass you are left wandering around the members section trying to find somewhere that you are allowed to sit/eat/bet. You had no idea whether a guard would welcome you into a zone or block your way. To aid matters, most lifts went to different selections of floors and seemed to be a bit random.The web site appears slick, but ultimately didn't offer us much practical info as to what to book. Having been there, it seems that there are some 'loges', pairs of seats with mini tables that overlook the start/finish lines, that appeared to be quite popular. If I went again then I'd look into booking one of those.All that to one side, seeing night time horse races surrounded by tower blocks is a very unique experience, and we are glad we did it, even though we were completely knackered from endless wandering.

Disappointing; confusing evening with 30 minutes between each race. We had a different experience from other reviewers; we found many of the staff unable to speak English. This was problematic, because upon entering we didn't know where to go (the Members/(tourist) section has a horrible layout with a patchwork of permitted/off-limit areas on different floors). We also didn't know how to bet, and then we had a hard time finding the apparently lone ATM location.With a lot of patience, perseverance, and walking we got betting instruction pamphlets and HK$2 pens from the 1st floor information desk. We then still filled out the wrong betting slips (there are different ones that look almost identical depending on whether you're using a machine vs a teller). We finally placed some bets, only to learn you have to sit around for 30 minutes between each race.The food in the Members III section was limited to mostly a small selection of meat + rice. The grandstand was smoky.Even getting to Happy Valley is confusing. If you take the bus from Admiralty and get off at what appears to be the racecourse stop, you are actually on the exact opposite side of the track and must walk ~1 mile around to the entrance.Overall, very disappointing after seeing Happy Valley rated as HK's #4 attraction.

Horse Racing at night - a greta experience in Hong Kong!!. if you are there in HK on a wed night - then head to the Race course at Happy Valley. the atmosphere is grt - more so because the races are held under lights... the cheapest entry fee is $10HK... this gets you at the ground level... closer to the food and beer and ring-side view. the prices keep going up and that means you can sit in the stands or even have a dinner date at the races... buy your tickets from the many booths within the area... i had no clue about which horse was good or bad, so i got hold of a detailed race chart for the day, that gave the past 10 performances of each horse, the name of the owner, its rating... etc... i thought that would help... hahaha, but it was not to be... but its always great betting on some unknown entity and then keeping your fingers crossed hoping that the entity can perform a miracle... the ambience was so good... hot dogs, beer, lots of yelling and screaming, and happy valley looks beautiful on a race night... so this is a must thing to do when in HK... there are usually 10 races in one night if i got the info correctly... min bet is $10HK...Address: Hongkong IslandDirections: in the middle of happy valley... if you take the tram, then get off at the last stop... pam-a-dei (i think) is what you call it locally... its known also as the jockey club...

What a night!!!. It was the last night of a 4 week trip(had been to Oz and stayed in Hong Kong for 4 nights to finish off) and we wanted to do something fun so headed to Happy Valley Racecourse and what a fantastic night we had!!! Was a Wednesday and was really busy and had a great atmosphere! Im not that into horseracing but totally loved it, seeing the horses in the parade ring before the races was fab.We had to ask how to fill in the race slips and the staff were very helpful and spoke perfect English too!We paid the 100 dollars to get into the members area (tourist pass) but we actually spent most of our time in the non members area so i dont think we really needed the tourist passes to be honest!There are a lot of regulars and if they put their newspapers over the seats (so they can go and put on bets) then dont sit in those seats!! we made that mistake and had an unhappy Chinese man come back to the seats we had sat in!! oops!Anyway, all in all a great fun night out and we won 4 races out of 8 which was fab!!

Great night out!. On my 2nd trip to Hong Kong I was finally able to make it to this in town race course for the Wednesday night races. And what a fun experience it was!One of our group found out that for HK100 (approx 13USD) you can get a "tourist" pass for the racecourse. This essentially allows you access to most areas of the course including the parade area and the standing space right by the finish line. It's easy to get the pass - just go into the lodge box entrance (not the main gate at the end) and you will see a sign for "tourist passes" The staff behind the window will check your passport (to make sure you have HK stamp) and then give you a small tag to attach to your shirt or pants once you have paid the fee. Inside the course you can get the racing forms and booklets. Placing bets was easy, although some of the options are different. In addition we discovered after a few races that it seems to be easier to win, so make sure you keep all of your tickets and bring them back to the window to double check. The only down side to the night was the food - we waited until late in the card to eat and didn't have very many options. I would suggest eating early or elsewhere. Getting to the course was easy - you can take the MTR to Times Square and once you are outside there are fairly obvious signs to the track. It is about a 10 min walk - you can also just get a cab ride which we did after with no problem. Finally on the night we were there the infield was full of beer tents and games for "Octoberfest" It seems like most weeks they have some sort of promotion or fun activity in this area. While this makes the racing some what less serious, it is a great distraction for those less interested in the horses. As a result we felt that the course had something for everyone in our group - the serious fans watches the races, reviewed the horses and made a few bets, while the rest of us enjoyed a few beers, met some interesting people and enjoyed the great night view. I would highly recommend adding this to your HK plans - I'm just sorry it took me a second trip to get out there!

Great night out- March 2008. Just a quick review - Me and my wife went to happy valley racecourse in March whilst in hong Kong and had a great night out. The setting is quite unique in among all the high rise buildings.It is not exspensive (in fact very cheap) there are lots of food/drink counters. Everything is in English and there are alot of very helpful staff on hand to help you out if needed!!There is no point in mentioning anything else which has not already been said in the previous review by Ajhaeh which is a very good review, apart from you will have a good night out!!

Fantastic experience. As Horse racing enthusiasts we couldn't resist the temptation of a little flutter when we found that there was a meeting at Happy Valley during our stay in Hong Kong.It was a Wednesday night meeting and following threads in the forum we headed for the Causway Bay MTR station about 2 hrs before the first race.. as we knew there would be one or two going along :)As you exit the MTR, follow the signs for Leighton Road and then the floodlights can be seen in the distance. It was well sign posted but by this time the crowds had started and we just followed along. We made our way to entrance E, the Members main entrance, where upon presentation of your passport you get a Members Day pass for 100 HKD. This entitles you to go anywhere in the massive stadium where a member can go. Any doubts on where that is, is easily decided by the vast number of staff on hand to help you. Everyone spoke English and the betting was explained and we sat above the winning post in the members enclosure. It was breathtaking looking up at the 9 or 10 storey high stands with all the punters duly awaiting the horses.Programmes in English were available and there was numerous food counters and coffee bars. There was a 'pomp' surrounding the occaision where the horses are led out by riders in a red uniform and the winner is then led to show off in front of the crowd. It was a fantastic evenings entertainment and another tick in the box.PS.. 1 winner & 3 places but the night was the winner :)
